context: Vergara-Fernández et al. (2008) successfully modeled mycelium growth in biofilters treating n-hexane, but this mathematical approach neglected the contribution of the non-aerial biomass. This work aims at developing an innovative experimental methodology to quantify the contribution of the aerial and non-aerial fungal biomass to n-pentane biodegradation. This information was used to construct a predictive mathematical model describing fungal growth and the continuous biodegradation of n-pentane using Fusarium solani as a model fungus. The model was further validated using an independent set of experiments. System definition The mathematical model developed aimed at describing the biodegradation of n-pentane by the filamentous fungus Fusarium solani and to quantify, for the first time, the contribution of the aerial and non-aerial biofilm. For this purpose, both the mass transfer of n-pentane from the bulk gas to the biomass and the biological consumption of this VOC by the fungal biomass were considered.
